commentBody: Ok, Ok.... Tars not Mars.... Who is Tom Waito again?
That was cute! But I felt like it helped to be old, to know some of those names. Still, I'll take what I can get.

Oh no!  Proper nouns as the theme? The horror!

The first I encountered -- TONY ORLANDO -- was my favorite.

initially  , i did a double take on the first three prime number clue. could it be, as simple as one, two, three?? but one is not a prime number, so the clue and answer  worked. I, too, liked the Tony Orlando answer the best.
I wasn't sure at first. I was a doubting Thomas. More please. I loved it.

Philosophy question...and answer....Every few days someone finds a reason to be triggered by an answer or a question in the puzzle....Typically under the category of "the editors mentioned a 'bad' person...so they must be supporting their bad acts".

One could look at this puzzle and research the past of all of the names referenced in both the cluse and answers....and find a bunch of imperfect people and bad acts.

And therein lies the problem with trying to to turn the NYT editors into cancellation machines.   Lots of people are imperfect...even bad....and sometimes they fit nicely in a crossword puzzle grid....and without the big newspaper headlines most people wouldnt think about their past's at all be it in the last decade...or half a century ago.
That was fun.  HAVANAther?
How fun! My favorite was ELLE FANNING; I had just been reading about her upcoming role as Thia, a Weyland-Yutani synthetic, in Predator: Badlands.

Quite an unpleasant solving experience. Finished it in about 35 minutes without assistance, but found the theme, theme answers, and the fill quite bad. Hope others felt otherwise.

That said, EOLIAN is a lovely entry, and "Certain canines" for EYETEETH is quite nice.

I hope this will be a recurring theme, because I'd love to do many more of these puzzle. Such fun. Tony Orlando was the first theme answer that fell for me and it gave me such a laugh. I really feel someone needs to open a posh central Florida restaurant with this name.
For 95D I immediately thought of BLOODY Sunday, but soon realized that it might fail the breakfast table test...

I've only done half the puzzle--but already, it's one of the funnest Sundays I've playing in quite a while. I could race through and finish, but I'll wait till tomorrow afternoon, and save the pleasure until then!
:-) :-) :-)

A rare Santa BARBARA appearance.

“Punk band the DKs caught an east ___ .”

BAY RAY

Not enough east bay clues!

While Steve Jobs was in the _____ has it, he invented the iPhone.






Et tu, emu.

Fun, super clever! I smiled the whole time and enjoyed the anticipation of each NAME reveal. (Note to Caitlin: "Vintage" is quite the euphemism for OLD. I'll have to start using that.) Loved 51A, 45D, and laughed out loud at the clue for 50D. Perfection. Thanks, Derrick! Question (if you're reading the comments): Can Tosswords be played with three or four people?

Such a fun theme, the kind I I GO GAGA over.  Well done Derrick! 

I love all the musical clues and entries…. TONY ORLANDO, BILL WITHERS, IRVING BERLIN, TOM WAITS,  Gloria Estefan (HAVANA), Peter, Paul & Mary (TRIO). BASSO, BASS HORN and OBOES. 

The concert promoters hyped the festival in the NY river valley as a night that would _______

ROCK HUDSON

Following up on my Caitlin-directed "vintage" comment re: old comics, what about this for a clue? 

Perhaps the comic MUTT and _______________ the gap between vintage and contemporary??
My review at Diary of a Crossword Fiend: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/09/06/sunday-september-7-2025/
High quality Sunday!  Thank you!
As a French Horn player in the John Phillip SOUSA band of Colorado I appreciate the crossing of Valves and Basshorn in this puzzle.
Whoo that was fast.
While I strive to be a Lady, Gaga for this puzzle I was not.

I’m surprised that the columnist didn’t point out that Ulysses _ Grant was forced to lose his middle initial in order to fit here. No one ever refers to him without that S., so that felt very forced to me.

Pretty medium difficulty so probably right for Sunday.  Certainly nothing like the past two days.

I didn't love the theme.  Most of it was a little too easy for my taste.  The Washington Irving clue seemed particularly simple minded.

Just my opinion obviously.  The puzzle overall was fine.  It took me slightly longer than I expected but probably just due to the usual Sunday size and my custom of reading through every clue...
I thought it was really clever.

"Did you hear IRVING BERLIN NOTATEd a RAGtime ORATORio? The latEST performance is touring regional NSW this EASTER. It stars ARIANA Grande with BILL WITHERS, TOM WAITS, and TONY ORLANDO performing the BASSO TRIO. BARBARA EDEN even has a LINE! Honestly, you'll SOB when the BASS HORN, EOLIAN harp and OBOES play the LEITMOTIF in ACT V."
...
"NOPE. I'm NOT STONED, you NINNY."

Today's puzzle was a joy. Loved the TRUE BLUE, dinky di Australiana answers too!

I loved this one! Very clever. And, the first NY Times Sunday crossword I have ever successfully completed without a single piece of assistance. I felt like I was on the same wavelength as the creator. A red letter day for me! 
Thanks for the fun and challenge!

The more I thought about the themers, the more I liked them: *both* names in the answer need to have a different meaning as it functions in the clue sentence.  It’s hard to think of good ones. (Anita and Lewis of course have risen to the occasion!)

I finally came up with a meh one:

We’re setting the have-a-heart trap in the garden tonight, to catch the wood- _____ -eating varmint.

And then another one which isn’t great because it’s not a real person, and it’s political. I’ll put it in a reply so anyone can just skip it.
I'm starting this puzzle at 4am as my baby is up for the 4th time tonight. I hope I'll enjoy it as much as the other posters did!

Looks like I'm in the minority here but this was an absolute slog. The themed clues didn't seem particularly witty and many of them seemed like very obscure (to me) American celebrities from a certain generation.

If I may nitpick - the correct term is MALAY peninsula and not MALAYA peninsula. If the reference was to the former name of Malaysia or the British colony, it should have been clued as such.

Gerald Ford was first and foremost a MICHIGAN Man.  Yes he went to Yale Law School, but you could have picked any number of Yalies.  Ford had The Victors, not the Yale fight song, played instead of Hail to the Chief.  He clearly bled Maiza and Blue!

Commenting on the Saturday puzzle, since I only just finished it (and surprisingly still got a Gold Star). Took me a day and a half of toying with it, 1:26 solve time.

Had very little time today, watching Juniors and Pro Women's Finals, going back to the puzzle during changeovers, but, hey, I got to meet the Kovackova sisters after they won. Then dinner with friends.

Finally was able to come up with MOVIETICKETS on the car ride home after deleting that whole section and starting over. That let me finish.

I'm not the right something-- generation? culture? region? area of obsession? -- to know most of the names, so it felt less fun than I'd have liked. But also I have a headache, so that didn't help. 

I like the idea of the theme though.
Took me 45 minutes to find my mistake, BELLE, not BELLA.  Ugh.
21A is a homophone!?!

Fun to see Charles and Ray EAMES in the puzzle. And who can forget that beautiful Rolling Stones song, TOM WAITS for No One? https://youtu.be/WKpEIVgHOGc?si=tT4a77doaEQbRhvr PS, Sotto Voce, are you out there?
RAG paper 34 across - made from linen or cotton is the highest quality - not sure if a ? covers that implication.
I had an Augie Doggie book when I was a kid! It was fun to see the reference.

The theme was a good idea.

The rest was not pleasant at all. (Sorry)

and 

the alt cru from the French gas station, Vin Diesel,

and

and

and, yes, I agree, that's about enough of that.

I really wanted 7A to be bald, not UPDO! Har! I thought it was a perfectly perfect answer... at least until I got to 20A and had to kill my little crossword darling. 

Oh well! On the bright side, somewhere in the recesses of the bingo ball cage of my brain, I pulled OILER out for 37D. Amazing!! I know zero about the NHL other than what I've learned in the puzzles. 

In all honesty, and you should know that I'd never lie to you fine folks, and if you can't believe me about me, who can you believe!? I digress, anyhow, this wasn't a favorite puzzle but not everything can be a favorite. Sounds like a lot of you really enjoyed it, which is super awesome, but it got a tad old for me. Got it all, just didn't enjoy it. 

Still, I did get a chuckle out of "An increase in ham prices forced the deli to MARKCUBAN sandwiches higher" at 68A.  That one amused me!!

In other bright news, the chili I made today turned out to be probably my best yet. So happy with it!! I don't make it very often but today was a perfect day for it... chilly, rainy, and blustery—and my poor dear of a husband had to work outside all day. Brr!

I blew through this puzzle, coming in 14 minutes under my average for a Sunday. And that's after not getting home from work until 9:30 pm and having a cocktail or two. This is a good example of a constructor being more concerned with the theme clues than the rest of the puzzle. Middling fill with fairly straightforward clueing. Frankly, I don't even think the theme is that clever. Give me a Saturday theme-less anytime.

I don't understand the TONY part of TONY ORLANDO as it pertains to the clue. I got all the other themers pretty readily but I'm lost on this one. What is the second meaning of TONY that the clue is implying?

Re: 24D: I was told there would be no math...

😉
It’s not the most challenging of Sunday puzzle (thank you), but I enjoyed every minute of this one.
Should the government be picking automaker winners and losers? Vice President _______: "It's a loan, not a bailout!"
Tosswords looks like fun! 😎

What a fun puzzle. I liked the theme, and EYETEETH for canines was so clever. Misled myself with cry for SOB and pest where BANE was the answer, but figured those out and was glad to see PEST find its place. 

I don’t understand two answers, though, please help. 67A solves to TWPS. I don’t know what that is an abbreviation for. And 110A, STET, is totally unfamiliar to me.
Fastest solve ever, but fun, fun, fun. Hadn't thought of Augie Doggie since I was about 10.
I cannot stand how much I absolutely LOVED LOVED LOVED this puzzle. Thank you again and again.

Derrick, I think your basketball clue would have been perfect! ELLE FANNING was the one that made me laugh out loud. Tossword looks like it’s right up my alley. Definitely ordering it for our Friday night Family game time!!

The wind god was Αίολος and thus aeolian. Had me debating whether there was a hidden rebus in the puzzle but finally decided it was just some dictionarian allowance. 

Malay peninsula I knew. MALAYA peninsula not. 

Much time spent in trying to find the mistake (an errant F instead of T …)

Nice puzzle. Doable through the crosses for most of the names for me but fun anyway. 

Thanks
Great crossword, imaginative and fun. Thanks.

Imagine that! ME feeling that a MATH professor had a lot in common with me? Well, this puzzle felt that way. It was very much on my wavelength.

The warehouse boss put the DOLLY PARTon the storeroom floor.
Nice idea for a theme, I feel like most of the names were too obscure for it to be fun though, maybe it's just me
Glad to see so many others pulled this one.  For me on the other hand, it felt like a slog, esp. the middle west area where LaoTse and Twps crossed Sauterne.
I’m still newish to crosswords, still need auto check but commenting because as a French Wines sales person located 40 miles from the village of Sauternes, the wine is SAUTERNES, not Sauterne.
Thanks Derrick. Lovely puzzle.
...is one not a prime number?

The crossing of EYETE_T_/_OLIAN and _EDGED defeated me. I've never heard of EYE TEETH, and there hardly seem to be two words that go together worse than those two 🤣.

I also had to look up some of the proper names outside the theme entries.

The trick was actually kinda fun: the right side of punny, for me (only just though!). However, Idon't get the TONY ORLAND entry. Apparently I'm not realizing what the world play there is about.
"a posh spot — TONY, of course" Yeah, OF COURSE, said as if that isn't the most obscure word to use for posh.

TIL that like Gerald Ford and William Howard Taft, the answer to 75A also applies to today's constructor. Boola boola! The puzzle felt like one huge, cringey dad joke. As a contemporary of Mr. Niederman and a father of four, I found it highly amusing. He's quite an interesting person and if you care to learn more about him, check out this 2009 Vanity Fair article: https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2009/09/squashs-numbers-guy?srsltid=AfmBOorT9OtJa_lbLUDrbN1j2Rm6Uh1TcHTTvARGkcJc3lfbBm1oeZOp BTW, Rex Parker did not care for the puzzle. Shocker, I know. Guy needs to find some bliss. Our own Eric Hougland reviewed the puzzle on "Diary of a Crossword Fiend" and supplied the link earlier in these comments. I always enjoy Eric's point of view.

I found these theme answers delightful.  They were fun to guess at with as few crosses as possible and when the answer hit, it brought a happy ping.  I loved the clues crafted out of thin air for DON LEMON and IRVING BERLIN.

The buoyant mood was bolstered by fun answers to say – GOGAGA, BASSO, EOLIAN, NINNY, AUGIE, BANFF, and HOBNOB (which is crossed by NAVE-SHAVE).

Not to mention a dook (ILED), UPDO appropriately in the top row, and an alternative answer to DOLLS for [Tiny house occupants] – the  nearby ANTS.

I’m glad I did this, Derrick, and grateful that you made it.  Thank you!
Shouldn’t Sauternes have an S on the end?

This was fun. Not hard, with a time well below my average, but still enjoyable.

One can easily imagine Will reading the theme clues as the quiz on Sunday Edition, but it might be a bit too much of a challenge without any crosses.

Thanks!

Liked HOBNOB and TRUEBLUE, and SHAVE next to NAVE brought a smile, but for the most part, the fill took a back seat to the theme entries. I get that. It was fun to suss out the name puns—the incomparable BILL WITHERS was my favorite—but otherwise a fairly rote solve.
Any puzzle with TOM WAITS gets an A+ from me.

Might be time to return to my home planet. This was a truly amazing puzzle and I did kind of catch on to the trick, but I still just got stuck in multiple places. Didn't come close to completing it. Actually surprised that everyone else found this unusually easy. 

That's just me. See you tomorrow.

...
Perhaps my favorite Sunday Puzzle ever. The cluing was magnificent and the theme entertaining. I look forward to Mr. Niederman’s next  Sunday submission!

Will Shortz
Please remove the ad from the top of the puzzle play space. It forces me to reduce the font to see the entire grid+clue, making it harder to play.
not a huge fan of proper name themes
Perhaps the most Boomer forward fill I've encountered here.
Totally unrelated to today's crossword, but I am so sad that the mini crossword is subscription only. Now only one or two of my friend's do it 😢
I amused myself by confidently putting in iBSEN as the "Buddy who played Jed Clampett", and then spent a couple of moments wondering whether an iMam might be a "Relative of a sultan".

I’ve got to agree with Jody Rosen and Ethan Hein: “Lean On Me” should be our national anthem.

Derrick, you are definitely NOT the Low Man (on the totem pole or any place else, I'd guess.)  Clever puzzle concept, fun solve, and only one Themer that was a bit OFF--(IMHO, Ulysses Grant doesn't really work.)  One nit:  AEOLIAN...I've never seen as EOLIAN, and it 

BILL WITHERS was one I didn't know...until a post-solve Google.  OMG, next time I'll know!  Slab Fork, WV.... do they have an historic marker up in his honor?
  Come to think of it, there are several names I got but whose claims to fame are a mystery to me.  

Looking forward to the next one!

I have a quibble with the clueing of 120A: “Eden on Earth” doesn’t make sense because, unlike Heaven, Eden WAS on Earth. 

Not especially important; just a garden variety complaint.

SAUTERNE crossed with TWPS? No, thank you.

Also, Heaven and Eden aren’t synonymous, so “EDEN on Earth” is clunky at best. It’s always been on Earth.

I’d like to thank Mr Niederman for the nice little streak-breaker.

Just as he clearly dipped into some rarely-seen crosswordese to fill in the last few squares while constructing this puzzle, so did I end up cheating to get those same squares.

I spent a good half hour staring at them before concluding that I was up against pure crosswordese and no realizations were forthcoming…and cheating confirmed this.

SAUTERNE x TWPS
and
EOLIAN x ILED

That said…I should have been able to deduce “I led”, but couldn’t convince myself 100% about the first “e” in TRENTI. That would have enabled me to get the ridiculous TWPS via brute force…but having uncertainty about multiple spots sunk me.
Oh, by the way, Derrick has been making crosswords for the Times for 43 years and is the longest running contributor to the Sunday puzzle.  I believe that's worth noting!
I have never heard of Tony used as posh. Never.

Re: 49D, The name of the wine, and the region, are both Sauternes.  With an S at the end.  

It is not SAUTERNE

["Can you tell Timmy to give me the ______ so I can walk the dog?"]

I loved this. I can understand if it was too vintage for some. And even those of us who grew up with many of the themers were mere tweens when Ulysses Shizzle Grant was prez.




YO-YO MA

And this one's even worse:

[One ought not disturb a hive or a bee might ____ you]
LEITMOTIF has not been in a crossword since 1954? Lovely bit of trivia. Thanks, Caitlin.

On man.  I had a mistake in "Fine as is, actually" and ended up with a "d" in the last spot which lead to this doozy. 

"How some risks are taken" my answer came out to be "Inabed" which I accepted because well though risqué l, it is in fact true. Lololol

I enjoyed this puzzle! Still in recovery from appendectomy, but doing great. There is a movie about Bill Withers, called "Stiil Bill," which is one of the best biographies ever. He was a remarkably wonderful person, and it is worth a watch.

It would be great of contributors would give the Across or 
Down Clue # in question, so that we can quickly locate the relevant clue or answer. Thanks.
Unfortunately for me, MICKEYMOUSE has the same number of letters as TONYORLANDO, so I lost a lot of time to a self-made red herring.

Quick - about a minute off my PB. Was surprised to find FANS/FANNING and also THIRTY/TRENTE in the same puzzle, but it didn't take from the fun.
Happy Football Sunday!

Took me a long time! 
I enjoyed most of it, some was frustrating - I love BILL WITHERS but I didn't know many of the others, and solved mainly through crossers. It didn't really sink in as a theme.

It's a big crossword and towards the last few clues I tired and ended up revealing a few of the more North American clues (I LED, SALEM, BEE, BANFF).

If Tosswords ever makes it here across the Atlantic - I'd suggest a  name change - tosser is a well-known but crude and offensive insult, and every time I read "Tosswords" I flinched!

I’m not a big fan of proper names being used in crosswords, in general. 

But a theme of proper nouns. Plus fill that also required (in my opinion) hard to spell proper nouns.  Not a recipe for fun (for me). 
If you gave me $100. I could not spell EBSEN, LAOTSE, SAUTERNE all correctly in one try. 

Unfortunately. I only knew three of the theme names. So that didn’t help. 

Not ‘mad’.  Got through it. But just to get through it. 

So hopefully. I’m the only one that didn’t find this ‘fun’. 

But in two hours. NFLredzone.  And I will be properly entertained!!!

Fun fun fun!

I caught on to the theme early and had great fun figuring out the rest of the themed answers. I managed to get through it with minimal googling and made my best Sunday time ever. Thanks for the enjoyable morning!

I've heard of a Township, but never in this context, only in the context of surveying property, as in Township, Section, and Range, but even then, I haven't ever seen it abbreviated. That was new to me

I will now have "Happy to Keep His Dinner Warm" in my head for the rest of the day. Thanks a lot, Derrick.

In a station wagon, to the Tarrytown PTA,
No, New Rochelle! New Rochelle PTA,

A fun and amusing, if not too difficult, Sunday puzzle. Took me just a few minutes more than my best time.  Yesterday's was a slog for me, 30 minutes more than my best time, so it is nice to have done well today.

Mickey went all out for their anniversary and got ___________ necklaces and diamond rings. 

For all the Hee Haw fans out there.

You never know what you're going to find/learn while rummaging through the comments, do you? I had no idea that SAUTERNE had an "s" at the end, and my pitiful excuse -- that I've had wine maybe three times in my life -- may not help my cause! I've certainly seen it without the closing "s" any number of times, but that excuse may be no better than my first one.  Sigh. My bad.

Was a little surprised to hear about the aversion to proper names. Sure, as a constructor, I have reworked many a corner to reduce its dependence on names, even well-known ones, but you've got me here: This was a theme built entirely on proper names, so I guess it was doomed at the outset for many of you.

Did the names skew to the old side? Maybe, but the majority are at least still alive (hooray for Barbara Eden!), and it's always hard to generate a well-rounded set -- and even if you do, the person who knows Bill Withers and Tom Waits may not be familiar with Elle Fanning, etc.

On that note, I'll close with one that I wasn't able to fit into the puzzle:

"Divas ____ performances become more popular."

No scrolling down to find the answer. I'm counting on the collective wisdom of this thread to prevail.

DCN

Unusual solving experience. Being a boomer, this was in my wheelhouse. I solved it with perhaps my fewest passes through the clues ever for a Sunday, but it still took my normal time. 

By the time I was ready to start on my second pass through the down clues I had only six incomplete words, and they fell easily. This felt ridiculously momentous. 

I can see why this was was difficult for people not in the US or in my demographic.

AEOLIAN is one of my favorite words, ever. Someone rigged up a gigantic aeolian harp outside of the arts building at UMASS a number of years ago and the sounds it made were unbelievably beautiful. If I ever retire, maybe I'll construct one.
Stupid number of proper nouns. Over and above the ones for the italic clues. Mixed in with obscure 122A, poor clues 21A and tedious repetitive non-words, 75A, 89A, v poor.

Augie Doggy and Doggy Daddy! Woo hoo!

I don’t understand people ragging on a puzzle because it’s not specifically geared to their wheelhouse. So you don’t know a lot of these proper names? Ok, move on. There’s another puzzle tomorrow. And the next day. And so forth. Isn’t the idea of a puzzle to challenge a person to think? Where is it written you have to “win” every puzzle every day? Do people get upset because it ruins their various streaks? I feel sorry for people who can’t just move on and have to bash a puzzle and its creator just because they couldn’t ace it. 

Ok. I’m done. Thanks for letting me get that off my chest.

**sigh** "In the United States, there is a semi-generic label for sweet white dessert wines known as sauterne without the "s" at the end and uncapitalized.[1]" E. McCarthy & M. Ewing-Mulligan: "French Wine for Dummies", pp. 73-77, Wiley Publishing 2001 ISBN 0-7645-5354-2. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sauternes_(wine)

I finished the puzzle, but it said there was a mistake. I finally checked, and the letter that was marked as incorrect was correct. When I deleted it and put it back in, it accepted it. Annoying, as I love to get the gold icon, especially on Sunday!

Initially thought we had a rebus puzzle going with my BeLLWtTHERS at 23A,  but cleaned that one up on the rebound.  Was good fun guessing the themers.  Well done. 

Busy day yesterday (campaign season has begun) so finished up yesterday's this morning too.   A nice workout that.

Loved it! Finished in just over three hours due to interruptions: feeding, walking and playing with our new Cockapoo puppy in a house filled with family here or the weekend to catch our catcher granddaughter's softball tournament. The proper name theme was ingenious, fun and right in my wheelhouse unlike most Sunday puzzle challenges. I'm listening to Bill Withers as I type.

I chortled audibly as each theme clue clicked. 

Oh, this was fun.

Fun puzzle and I liked the punny nature of the names though a couple made me groan 😩. I do think that 12D could be clued a little clearer. The peninsula in question is MALAYSIA and encompasses parts of Thailand, Myanmar and Malaysia, also formerly known as MALAYA (under various versions) until 1963. Perhaps the clue might have offered a little more clarity as Malaya to denote the country, though not other uses, have fallen into obscurity. It would be like calling Myanmar BURMA or Beijing PEKING without acknowledging the historical change. Perhaps the editors should have caught this. Otherwise, I really liked the puzzle. 👍🏽

ULYSSESGRANT was fun but the rest were take it or leave it. Didn’t like YALEMAN one bit, was hunting around for YALEEAN or YALIEAN or YALIEREAN or some such. Took a chance on ENOL to complete the SW corner.

Had COLA instead of COCA and somehow convinced myself that it was intoxicating and that ALTV was some obscure theater reference. Shakespeare could have signed off on”AltV”, couldn’t he have? Sure he could have.

Finally at 1:36:01 decided to use the wordplay column for DONLEMON and complete it. Oh well!

Well, if I needed any further proof that I am indeed a millennial.... The excitement when I saw the ELLEFANNING clue. "Wait, I KNOW that one!" 😂 
This was a fun theme, even if I wasn't familiar with some of the names. I think the DONLEMON clue was my favorite.
Now this crossword, I really enjoyed. It was fun. More....

I loved this so much! Figured out the theme pretty early on, which was fun, but the whole rest of the puzzle was just the right level for a Sunday, for me. With nothing else planned for the day, it saw me through lunch and two laundries...oh... I mean, it saw my husband through two laundries. I guess it's my turn to get up and do something now. 

(He's really too good for me. I don't deserve him.)

I really found this puzzle enjoyable.  The fills were often groaners, but made me smile.  TONYORLANDO was the first one I got, slowly followed by the others.  Amazing that Derrick has been constructing NYT puzzles for so long.  There was also an almost total absence of current pop culture, one of my personal bugaboos, but I live with them.

As I scrolled through the comments, I was once again struck by the often nit picking points that many solvers make. Case in point, SAUTERNE.  I knew that the French region and eponymous wine names end in “s”.  I am sure, however, that, as others have pointed out, that American wine makers take liberties with names and drop that letter.  To all you oenophiles, this is a crossword puzzle, not a Wine Spectator article.  Lighten up.

Kudos Derrick for starting my Sunday morning off on the right foot and putting a smile on my face.
Fun puzzle theme and almost beat my record. But there is something a little sad when it’s solved so quickly.

This was an oddball you since, kind of a reverse difficulty for Sunday - I got the theme pretty quickly, which is usually the tricky part, but this time around the rest of the fill was what gave me trouble. Plenty of unfamiliar words or names that I had to puzzle over for longer than normal, but I got there in the end,and had a good time overall. The most interesting piece was figuring out EOLIAN by crossing answers - I have no recollection of that term, and I have a whole background in weather science! I guess there's always room to learn something new.

So, cruising more of the comments today, I am surprised by the townships issue that many expressed. I had the reverse problem in a way.  I grew up in a small town in Southeastern Wisconsin and called another small town nearby home until I was almost 30, when I moved to Minnesota.  I had no idea that not every place had towns or townships. 

Of course, I did get it, but the answer to that one didn't come to me immediately because I thought it had to be something more than the little old place I'm from. Funny that!
Omg such a fun witty Sunday - my first theme clue was ELLE FANNING and I’ve figured out 2 more names. Super fun. Thank you! Back to my puzzle…
Horrible. Don't know who half these people are and the other half I never would've thought of in these sentences. Glad other people liked it I guess.

Solved it with only one mistake/look up (The EAMES Brothers got me) which is a miracle for the Sunday so-big puzzle. 

I liked the theme and enough clues to keep me off-balance and thinking.
Re: TWPS https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Township_(United_States)

His West Point buddies called him Sam. He didn't like the initials of H.U.G. and his family called him Ulysses anyway.  The politician who recommended him for West Point didn't know him too well and assumed his first name was Ulysses and stuck the S. in there either for his mother (who  was a Simpson) or from getting him mixed up with a brother whose name was Simpson. The West Point bureaucrats didn't bother with correcting his name, and his classmates began calling him U.S. Grant for "Uncle Sam", and then just Sam. @Sarah It isn't considered a prime number. Prime numbers having "only two divisors, 1 and itself" doesn't allow those divisors to be the same number. It would complicate maths and overthrow some principles to overlook that and count 1 as prime.

@Sarah

Actually, there was a time when it was up in the air whether one was a prime number, but mathematicians have come to an agreement (and formalized it by putting "any number greater than one..." in the definition), for the reason Aarglefarg stated.

@Steve L to add to this, though, that decision was made a looooong time ago—nobody alive now should have been taught that 1 is prime. 

(I’m not saying they weren’t—knowing first-hand that at least one teacher in Arkansas taught her class that X*0 = X—just that they should never have been taught that, if they were.)

@Aarglefarg
Both 1 and zero have all sorts of exceptions because of their unique roles in math. Each is an operator that allows its object to retain its identity. For multiplication or division, 1 x X or X/1 = X. For addition, X+0 or X-0=X. In exponents, things 
get even stranger.  X*1=X. And X*0=1. Surprise! 
When you think about it, how is either of them a number?! What exactly are they "counting"?

No.  That's why it's the loneliest.

@Times Rita @Eric Hougland Here's the article (part 1)

Squash has its share of unusual personalities. Derrick Niederman—former Yale No. 1, onetime 35-and-over national champion, mathematics PhD from M.I.T., crossword-puzzle constructor, mystery writer, and investment counselor—is one of them.

I sat down with Niederman not far from the Squash and Tennis Club in Newton, Massachusetts, of which he is president. He has a new book out, Number Freak: From 1 to 200—the Hidden Language of Number Revealed.

It's a fun book, but definitely challenging. The entry for number 19, for instance, both explains why Kellogg's named its response to General Mills' Total cereal "Product 19"—it was the company's 19th product since the introduction of Kellogg's Corn Flakes—and dilates on philosopher Bertrand Russell's quest to identify "the least integer not nameable in fewer than nineteen syllables." Niederman calls the book "a painless introduction to numbers for the intellectually curious, and it doesn't presuppose that they are crazy about the subject."

@Times Rita Part 2
So where is the squash content, I asked? His "investment mystery novel," A Killing on Wall Street had several scenes at the exclusive Apawamis Club, in Rye. Likewise, Niederman, who has contributed about 20 puzzles to the Sunday New York Times, once famously constructed a squash puzzle in the shape of a racket for the old U.S. Open tournament in Boston. (Sample impenetrable clue: "What did a tired Kenton Jernigan say after winning the intercollegiate championship?" Answer: "Boyumibeat," referring to Jernigan's victory over David Boyum, a Harvard champion who went on to collaborate with Niederman on an earlier book, What the Numbers Say: A Field Guide to Mastering Our Numerical World.)

There is no squash content, it turns out. So I asked the only two squash-related number questions I could think of: 1. With three different scoring systems kicking around—games to 15, 11, or 9—which one is right for me? 2. How many points do you choose to play at deuce? One or two?

On query one: The 54 year old Niederman, a hardball player at heart, favors the new, point-after-rally scoring system to 11. "If you are looking to end points, the way a hardball player does, that scoring benefits you," he explains. And it also benefits the older player over the younger player. "You can close out a good lead," he says. "You don't get hung up dueling on individual points."

Charles and Ray EAMES: https://static.vitra.com/media/asset/1545513/storage/v_fullbleed_1440x/16820217.jpg

@Bill a few thoughts LEITMOTIF and EOLIAN--not wrong, just ugly. I prefer to play that menacing, minor-second leitmotiv on my aeolian harp (or better, "æolian.") But nice touch to clue LEITMOTI(v/F) to John William's music--a couple years ago, I watched all nine of the Star Wars movies, in (release) order. Those soundtracks gave me new respect for Williams as a composer--throughout the course of the movies, he repeats, modifies, develops, connects the musical themes with all the complexity of Wagner's Ring cycle. It was my favorite part of the movies! Well, that and Queen Amidala's outfits. Speaking of Romantic composers-- The BASS HORN isn't just a lower version, of, well, a (French) horn--it's a whole other thing, which falls into that class of weird wind instruments, neither brass nor woodwind, which includes cornetti, serpents, and ophecleides. They're mostly considered historical curiosities nowadays, which is a pity, as they have a snarly sound so different from modern tubas etc. Apparently scored his Overture to a Midsummer Night's Dream to include bass horns, but I couldn't find a good, period-instrument recording. However, here's Roger Norrington leading the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment, in the March from Berlioz' Symphony Fantastique, whose orchestration includes the closely related ophecleides. Listen, and watch, for them about 2:00: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=73wj7MC9is0&list=RD73wj7MC9is0&start_radio=1
